title: How to Dress up a Porch

methods.name: Dress Up Your Porch with Flowers

steps.headline: Place pots or hanging baskets of flowers on your porch.
steps.description: You can decide on a color scheme that complements your home's exterior, or you can choose an assortment of your favorite flowers and plants.

steps.headline: Put potted plants on a set of shelves or a festive outdoor table if your porch cannot accommodate hanging baskets.
Use flowers and potted plants to fill in empty or hard to reach spaces, such as the corner of the porch where nothing else will fit.
steps.description: Or, try placing a tall potted plant between two chairs if there isn't enough space to accommodate a small table.

steps.headline: Arrange small pots of flowers on the edges of each step if you have stairs leading up to the porch.
steps.description: Your porch steps should be at least 6 feet (1.8 m) wide so that the pots don't interfere with foot traffic.

methods.name: Dress Up Your Porch with Furniture

steps.headline: Consider balance and scale when you are choosing pieces of furniture to put on your porch.
steps.description: Even if your porch is very large, you should arrange your furniture proportionally. You can use masking tape or painter's tape to mark off the spaces for the furniture you have in mind. That way, you'll know if the pieces you have in mind will fit comfortably on your porch and whether or not your arrangement as a whole will look balanced.

steps.headline: Try placing a small chair or table on either side of your front door.
steps.description: While it is ideal for your decorative touches to have functionality as well as appeal, placing small pieces on either side of your main entrance is very welcoming.

steps.headline: Situate two small love seats or two chairs at an angle or across from each other to create a space for casual or intimate conversation.
steps.description: This seating arrangement is far more inviting than having all your seating facing in one direction, such as towards the street.

steps.headline: Add a small table lamp or wall sconce if your porch has an outdoor electrical outlet.
steps.description: Soft lighting creates a wonderful ambiance during the evening hours.

steps.headline: Put a piece of lattice work on any side of your porch that faces the street or a neighbor.
steps.description: The lattice lets in light, but provides some shade and privacy.

methods.name: Dress Up Your Porch with a Fresh Coat of Paint

steps.headline: Paint your porch floor with weatherproof, outdoor paint.
steps.description: Get as creative as you wish and use several colors and paint a geometric design. If you want your design to look more like a rug, paint “fringes” on each end of your design. Paint will also protect your floor from the elements, so it's a good idea to paint your porch floor even if you plan to use rugs.

steps.headline: Use a contrasting paint color to highlight the trim around your door or porch windows.
Give your porch columns or railings a fresh coat of paint.

methods.name: Dress Up Your Porch with New Flooring

steps.headline: Use an outdoor rug that complements your furniture.
steps.description: A patterned rug with warm colors will give your porch a nice, homey touch.

steps.headline: Choose a large area rug if your porch can accommodate one.
steps.description: Make sure it is slip-resistant and made for outdoor use.

steps.headline: Put a rug or straw mat underneath a coffee table or end table.

methods.name: Dress Up Your Porch with New Accessories

steps.headline: Use the outside wall of your porch to hang mirrors.
steps.description: They will reflect light and scenery.

steps.headline: Look for attractive, affordable artwork at flea markets to hang on your porch wall.
Add a wall sconce on either side of your entry door.
steps.description: You don't have to wire them if you don't want to; just hang them so that no wires are exposed, or hang candle sconces.

steps.headline: Drape curtains over the top of a porch window.
steps.description: You can get 2 curtain panels and drape them over a rod and let them hang loosely on either side of the window frame.

steps.headline: Hang flowing curtains in the front or on 1 or more sides of your porch.
steps.description: You can use a curtain rod or a piece of copper tubing and attach the curtains with clips. Tie the curtains back on windy days or rearrange them throughout the day to filter the sun.

steps.headline: Hang twinkling lights on your porch.
steps.description: They don't have to necessarily be Christmas light; think of how outdoor restaurants use mood lighting in the evening to create a warm glow outdoors. You can do the same on your porch.
